author: Staff Reporter
text:
Eight witnesses, including government officials, were produced on Wednesday as examination of the second batch of witnesses continued for the second day at the Principal District and Sessions Court here.

All the accused, including O. Raja, brother of Finance Minister O. Paneerselvam, were present.

Madurai Government Rajaji Hospital doctor Juliana Jayanthi, handwriting expert K. Kumar of Madurai, Tahsildar Ramesh, Deputy Tahsildar Pratiba, Periyakulam RDO Rajarathinam, Sri Kailasanathar Temple Executive Officer Balakrishnan and two constables – Ramesh Kannan and Sangili Murugan – were examined by both Special Public Prosecutor B. Mohan and defence counsel M. Kannappan.

A portion of the statement made by Mr. Rajarathinam during cross examination was treated as hostile. Mr. Balakrishnan stated that the temple was brought under the control of Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments department long ago and no one, except security personnel, was allowed to stay in the temple at night.

Mr. Kumar admitted that there was no proper procedure to compare Tamil scripts and no specific method to compare Tamil handwriting. Procedures were available only to compare English and Devanagiri scripts, he said.

Later, Principal District Judge R. Poornima adjourned the case till Thursday.

Three witnesses have turned hostile in the case so far.

S. Nagamuthu (22) of T. Kallupatti village, a Dalit, who worked as pujari in Sri Kailasanathar Hill Temple in Periyakulam committed suicide by hanging on December 8, 2012, after he was allegedly subjected to harassment.
title: Eight witnesses examined in pujari suicide case
